sub_title: Scenography is about making spaces talk.
summary:
I began my professional journey in 2010 with Siddhartha Das Studio in Delhi, India, as an exhibition designer, working with a team of curators and traditional miniature painters & craftspeople to execute the scenography at a heritage monument. For the next 5 years, I was a part of the core scenography team at Rajeev Sethi Scenographers, Delhi, India. We executed the permanent exhibition for the Mumbai International Airport, currently Asia’s largest Art Program. Together we worked with more than a hundred artists to develop the spatial staging. Post that, I worked in different fields of design such as Lighting Design, Way-finding and Signage, Environment Branding, etc. After which I practiced as an independent designer and executed several Exhibitions.

I have also been practicing as a collage artist since 2017, applying the same knowledge of building narratives, and have done several commissions and exhibitions since. I recently graduated as a Master in Scenography in HKU Utrecht, Netherlands, where I am also based currently.

profile_positions.description:
Time to Love- Pero exhibition, Delhi, India (1st February-13th March 2020)
Exhibition Design Supervision in collaboration with Oddworks
An episodic presentation of practice of péro: completing ten, unexpected years of making clothes,
housed in an old building on Barakhamba Road in Delhi. 

Mahindra Sanatkada Lucknow Festival, Lucknow, India
(2nd-6th February, 2018; 1st-5th February 2019; 31st January-4th February 2020)
Graphic & Exhibition Designer
The festival theme roots squarely in the city of Lucknow, allowing to explore different facets from the historic to the culinary; from communities to film and traditional clothes to the season of spring. Every year a theme of historical and cultural relevance to Lucknow is chosen and translated into oral, visual and experiential storytelling techniques.

Desi Oon, Khamir, Bikaner House, Delhi, India (10th-13th January 2020)
Graphic Design & Exhibition Design Supervision
Khamir brought a multi-media exhibition on wool-craft of Kutch to Delhi. Straddling across themes
of ecology, local-economies, artisanship, and community inter-being, the exhibition unfurled the yarn
of wool and how it manages to tie seemingly the most diverse of things. The exhibition blended artist
installations, photo-essays, films, curated sales, workshops, and artisan interactions to create a space for
inspiration, reflection, and discussion.

Living Lightly: Journey With Pastoralists, India (2nd-18th December 2016, 5th-8th October 2017)
Graphic & Exhibition Designer
Living Lightly: Journey With Pastoralists, a travelling exhibition, curated by Sushma Iyengar and
organized by the Centre for Pastoralism was co-designed by me in collaboration with Sahjeevan and
the Foundation for Ecological Security held in December 2016 at IGNCA, New Delhi, and subsequently
in October 2017 at ATMA, Ahmedabad supported by the Ministry of Culture. The exhibition offered an
insight into the lightly lived lives of nomadic tribes of herdsmen from the Banni region of Kutch.

profile_positions.description:
The scope of work included conceptualization of lighting design for a township (India) exploring ways of dramatizing spaces after dark, encouraging people to linger on in the community spaces making them safe, secure and adding elements that would increase their interaction with the urban-scape.

Observing the specific character of each space in the township (plazas, children’s park, herbal garden,
pool areas) and developing it into its unique identity. Researching on an integrated approach for road lighting where it isn’t an independent system but responds to other landscape/ urban elements, making it a part of the street furniture. Exploring methods and possibilities of Facade lighting (residential condo) which minimally defines the architecture of the building, at the same time creating a narrative at the skyline level which distinguishes the residential condo from the rest of the township.

profile_positions.description:
As a part of the core scenography team, we developed 'Jaya he', Asia’s largest public art initiative till now, for Mumbai International Airport (India). The scenography was interpreted through six thematic installations
composed of 4000 artefacts juxtaposed with artworks by India’s finest traditional and contemporary
artists at the Airport Terminal 2, India. Jaya He was conceived as an initiation into the immediate environment and the larger context of the airport, the city of Mumbai and of India as a whole. Reflecting the many-layered story that is India, the collection evolved into an immense multidisciplinary endeavor, like a new museum.
Jaya He brought together designers, artists, artisans, architects, art historians, anthropologists,
and conservators with the technicians, all working together to distill and interpret India culturally,
aesthetically, historically and socially in a manner that leaves visitors with no doubt that they are in the
heart of the South Asian subcontinent.

The project has three sections to it, namely, Thresholds of India, Layered Narratives and Baggage
Acclaimed.

profile_positions.description:
Assisting Principle Scenographer, Design Developer, Artist Liasioning, Production & Execution Supervisor
for a permanent exhibition, part of restoring a heritage monument of its art. The walls of 'Jal Mahal' (India) are
an exhibition bringing together Jaipur’s (Rajasthan, India) leading artists and crafts persons for the first time to engage all the senses on a journey where past and present meet in a dynamic celebration of Rajasthan’s artistic traditions, as seen through centuries of royal patronage.

The scenography of the Jal Mahal (Water Palace) interiors is titled Painted Pleasures and illustrates the
notion of pleasure pavilions, celebrating the Rajput courtly arts of the 18th century India. The curators
selected the main exhibits and the text around which the space has been visualized and about 40 art
works have been conceived while collaborating with 30 traditional miniature painters and craftspeople.
The project blends design with art, craft and architecture.
